key_findings: "**OAuth 2.0 for Authorization, OpenID Connect (OIDC) for Authentication:** While OAuth 2.0 is an authorization framework, OIDC builds on top of it to provide identity layer, making it suitable for user login and registration flows by providing an `id_token` (JWT) with user identity information.",

"**JWTs as Bearer Tokens:** JSON Web Tokens (JWTs) are the standard format for access tokens and ID tokens in OAuth/OIDC. They are self-contained, digitally signed, and often encrypted, allowing resource servers to validate them without directly querying the authorization server for every request.",

"**Separation of Concerns:** The Identity Provider (IdP) handles user authentication (login/registration) and issues tokens. The Client Application (frontend) initiates the OAuth flow. The Resource Server (backend API) validates tokens to grant access to protected resources (dashboard data).",

"**Authorization Code Flow with PKCE is Standard:** For web and mobile applications (public clients), the Authorization Code Flow with Proof Key for Code Exchange (PKCE) is the recommended and most secure OAuth 2.0 flow for obtaining tokens.",

"**Access Token vs. Refresh Token:** Access tokens (JWTs) are short-lived and used to access protected resources. Refresh tokens are long-lived, securely stored, and used to obtain new access tokens when the current one expires, minimizing re-authentication.",

"**Statelessness and Scalability:** JWTs enable stateless authentication on the resource server side, as all necessary user information and claims are contained within the token itself, reducing database lookups per request and improving scalability.",

"**Secure Token Storage is Critical:** Access tokens should be stored securely (e.g., HTTP-only, secure cookies for web; secure storage for mobile). Refresh tokens must be stored with even greater care due to their long lifespan and power.",

"**Comprehensive Token Validation:** Resource servers must rigorously validate JWTs, including signature, expiration, issuer, audience, and any custom claims, to prevent unauthorized access and token tampering."
